title: Collisions - energy change of inelastic collision

content.question: A <math alttext="4.0 kilogram" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>4.0</mn><mtext>-kg</mtext></math> object initially moving at <math alttext="5.0 meters per second" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>5.0</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>m/s</mtext></math> has a perfectly inelastic collision with a <math alttext="2.0 kilogram" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2.0</mn><mtext>-kg</mtext></math> object initially moving in the opposite direction at <math alttext="1.0 meter per second" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1.0</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>m/s</mtext></math>. What is the absolute value of the change in mechanical energy of the two-object system as a result of this collision?

choices.label: <math alttext="51 joules" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>51</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">J</mi></math>
<math alttext="32 joules" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>32</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">J</mi></math>
<math alttext="24 joules" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>24</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">J</mi></math>
<math alttext="8 joules" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>8</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">J</mi></math>

content.answer: <math alttext="24 joules" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>24</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">J</mi></math>
